text:
I have a function that takes two arguments. One of those arguments is a function, and the other argument is mutated by my function. Which argument order makes more sense?
1. `myfunction!(f::Function, thing_that_gets_mutated)`
2. `myfunction!(thing_that_gets_mutated, f::Function, )`

elements.text: I have a function that takes two arguments. One of those arguments is a function, and the other argument is mutated by my function. Which argument order makes more sense?

text: Putting the function first allows one to use the `do... end` syntax, so it's the usual and recommended order.

elements.text: Putting the function first allows one to use the
syntax, so it's the usual and recommended order.

text: The answer is the same, but I use the style guide to decide on stuff like this: <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/style-guide/#Write-functions-with-argument-ordering-similar-to-Julia-Base>
